message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The feature of the electrocardiogram that represents initial ventricular depolarization is the Q wave, which is normally less than 40 milliseconds in duration. Therefore, option (C) is correct. Option (A) is incorrect because hypokalemia can lead to a prolonged QRS complex, not a prominent Q wave. Option (B) is incorrect because full thickness ischemic injury of the heart can lead to elevated ST segments on the electrocardiogram, not a prominent Q wave. Option (D) is incorrect because a normal QRS complex duration is less than 100 milliseconds, not less than 200 milliseconds.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Initial ventricular depolarization is represented by the Q wave on the ECG, and it is considered normal when it is less than 120 milliseconds in duration. Options A and B are not related to initial ventricular depolarization, and option D is incorrect as it defines the entire QRS complex duration rather than just the Q wave.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Initial ventricular depolarization is represented by the Q wave in the ECG, which is a small negative wave that is normally less than 120 milliseconds in duration. Hypokalemia would result in abnormal T waves, and full thickness ischemic injury of the heart would result in elevated ST segments. The duration of less than 200 milliseconds applies to the entire QRS complex, not just the Q wave.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The initial ventricular depolarization is represented by the QRS complex on the electrocardiogram. It is normal duration defined as less than 120 milliseconds. Option A is incorrect because hypokalemia may cause a prominent U wave, not the QRS complex. Option B is incorrect because full thickness ischemic injury is represented by ST elevation, not the QRS complex. Option D is incorrect because a duration of less than 200 milliseconds is too broad and includes other waves on the electrocardiogram.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The initial ventricular depolarization corresponds to the Q wave on the electrocardiogram. Its normal duration is less than 120 milliseconds. Option A is incorrect because hypokalemia prolongs the QRS complex, not the Q wave. Option B is incorrect because full thickness ischemic injury is associated with ST segment elevation, not changes in the Q wave. Option D is incorrect because a QRS duration less than 200 milliseconds is considered normal, but it encompasses the Q wave and subsequent depolarization.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The initial ventricular depolarization is represented on the ECG as the Q wave, which is normally less than 120 milliseconds in duration. Options A and B are not consistent with the Q wave, and option D is too broad, as it includes other waves such as the R wave.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Initial ventricular depolarization is represented by the Q wave on the ECG, which is normal in duration and should be less than 120 milliseconds. Hypokalemia can lead to changes in the T wave and ST segment, while full thickness ischemic injury would result in elevated ST segments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The initial ventricular depolarization is represented by the Q wave, which is normally less than 120 milliseconds in duration. Option A is incorrect because hypokalemia affects the ST segment and T wave, not the Q wave. Option B is incorrect because full thickness ischemic injury would result in ST segment elevation, not changes in the Q wave. Option D is also incorrect because a Q wave duration of less than 200 milliseconds would be abnormally prolonged.

We refer to as ECG (electrocardiogram) on Wikipedia. The part of the ECG that represents initial ventricular depolarization is the Q wave. The duration of the Q wave is normally less than 120 milliseconds. Option A is incorrect because hypokalemia leads to the flattening of T waves on the ECG, not Q waves. Option B is incorrect because full-thickness ischemic injury of the heart produces ST-segment elevation on the ECG, not Q waves. Option D is incorrect because a Q wave duration of less than 200 milliseconds is considered normal for males, but the question does not provide the patient's gender.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The initial ventricular depolarization is represented by the Q wave on the electrocardiogram. It has a normal duration of less than 120 milliseconds. Option A is incorrect as hypokalemia does not affect the Q wave. Option B is incorrect as full thickness ischemic injury of the heart would affect the ST segment, not the Q wave. Option D is incorrect as a Q wave duration of less than 200 milliseconds is not specific for initial ventricular depolarization.
